channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Atomic ‘conveyor belt’ boosts power of quantum computer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03002-x

Array system could help to scale up technology that uses atoms to create qubits.
item.dc:title: Atomic ‘conveyor belt’ boosts power of quantum computer
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Analogue speech recognition based on physical computing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09501-1

A temporal-signal processor based on two in-materia computing hardware platforms—reconfigurable nonlinear-processing units (RNPUs) and analogue in-memory computing (AIMC)—is used for both feature extraction and classification, advancing compactness, efficiency, and performance of heterogeneous smart edge devices.
item.dc:title: Analogue speech recognition based on physical computing
item.dc:creator: Mohamadreza Zolfagharinejad
Julian Büchel
Lorenzo Cassola
Sachin Kinge
Ghazi Sarwat Syed
Abu Sebastian
Wilfred G. van der Wiel

item.title: Addressing the safety of next-generation batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09358-4

Next-generation batteries will present different risks to conventional lithium-ion cells, emphasizing the need for efforts towards characterizing the abuse tolerance and hazards associated with next-generation battery materials over their life cycle and providing the data in the context of supporting affected professionals.
item.dc:title: Addressing the safety of next-generation batteries
item.dc:creator: Chuanbo Yang
Avtar Singh
Xiaofei Pu
Anudeep Mallarapu
Kandler Smith
Matt Keyser
Michael R. Haberman
Hadi Khani
Pawel Misztal
Ryan Spray
Ofodike A. Ezekoye
Donal P. Finegan

item.title: Toughened self-assembled monolayers for durable perovskite solar cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09509-7

Cross-linkable co-SAMs improve hole-selective SAM stability, preventing defects and thermal degredation in perovskite solar cells, enabling 26.92% efficiency with high heat durability, and guiding the design of more efficient and durable solar cells.
item.dc:title: Toughened self-assembled monolayers for durable perovskite solar cells
item.dc:creator: Wenlin Jiang
Geping Qu
Xiaofeng Huang
Xia Chen

Tonghui Wang

Jie Zhang
Alex K.-Y. Jen

item.title: Atomic-scale imaging of frequency-dependent phonon anisotropy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09511-z

A new form of momentum-selective electron energy-loss spectroscopy enables the element-resolved imaging of frequency- and symmetry-dependent vibrational anisotropies with atomic resolution.
item.dc:title: Atomic-scale imaging of frequency-dependent phonon anisotropy
item.dc:creator: Xingxu Yan
Paul M. Zeiger
Yifeng Huang
Haoying Sun
Jie Li
Chaitanya A. Gadre

item.title: A room temperature rechargeable all-solid-state hydride ion battery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09561-3

A core-shell hydride 3CeH3@BaH2, which exhibits fast H− conduction at ambient temperature and becomes a superionic conductor above 60 °C, is used to construct an all-solid-state rechargeable H− battery.
item.dc:title: A room temperature rechargeable all-solid-state hydride ion battery
item.dc:creator: Jirong Cui

item.title: A photonic chip enables ultrabroadband wireless communication
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02965-1

Future wireless networks should exploit the full range of telecommunications frequencies. A photonic chip that can reconfigure a broad range of frequencies enables dynamic, full-spectrum management of next-generation communications systems.
item.dc:title: A photonic chip enables ultrabroadband wireless communication
